questions.text: The longest fetal diameter is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Mentovertical diameter

 

  • Mentovertical diameter is the longest fetal diameter
  • It is seen when the presenting part is the brow

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Biparietal diameter is the engaging diameter (Transverse diameter) in cephalic presentation; it measures 9.5 cm
  • Option B: Suboccipitobregmatic diameter: This is the presenting diameter in a well flexed head; it measures 9.5 cm.
  • Option C: Occipito-frontal diameter: This is the presenting diameter in a deflexed head. It measures 11.5 cm

 

Educational Objective:

 

DIAMETERS OF FETAL SKULL

 

 

Ref: Page no 92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: In the pelvic inlet, which is the shortest anteroposterior diameter?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Obstetric conjugate

 

  • The obstetric conjugate is the shortest antero-posterior diameter of the pelvic inlet and measures 10 cm.

 

Other options

 

  • Option A: True conjugate: True (anatomical) conjugate (11 cm): Extends from uppermost margin of symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory.
  • Option C: Anatomical conjugate: This is another name for the true conjugate: Extends from uppermost margin of symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory. It measures 11 cm.
  • Option D: Bispinous diameter (10 cms) is the transverse diameter of the mid-pelvis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diameters of the Pelvic Inlet

 

Anteroposterior (AP) Diameter

 

  • True (anatomical) conjugate (11 cm): Extends from uppermost margin of symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory.
  • Obstetric conjugate (10 cm): It is the shortest AP diameter of the pelvic inlet and hence obstetrically most important. It is measured from the middle of sacral promontory to symphysis pubis. It cannot be measured directly on clinical examination. It is calculated by subtracting 1.5 cm from diagonal conjugate.
  • Diagonal conjugate (12.5 cm): It is measured from tip of sacral promontory to the lower margin of pubic symphysis. It is the only diameter that can be assessed clinically.

 

Transverse Diameter (13 cm)

 

  • Distance between the farthest two points on the iliopectineal line.
  • It is the largest diameter of pelvic inlet

 

Oblique Diameters (12 cm)

 

  • Right oblique diameter: Passes from right sacroiliac joint to left ilio-pubiceminence
  • Left oblique diameter: Passes from left sacroiliac joint to right ilio-pubic eminence

 

Ref: Page no 92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: After delivery, a mother notices a swelling on the baby’s head in the occipital region. The pediatrician tells her it is caput succedaneum and will disappear by itself. She is very concerned and asks you, the resident, how long it will take to resolve?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Within 24–48 hours

 

  • A caput succedaneum usually disappears within 24-48h of birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 92, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

choices.text: All are equal in length

questions.text: The shortest transverse diameter of the fetus is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Bimastoid diameter

 

  • The shortest transverse diameter of the fetus is the mastoid diameter

 

Other Options:

 

  • Biparietal diameter: This measures 9.5cm
  • Bitemporal diameter: This measures 8cm

           

Educational Objective:

 

DIAMETERS OF FETAL SKULL

 

 

Ref: Page no 92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: Which pelvic dimension is being measured in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Diagonal conjugate

 

  • Diagonal conjugate is the only pelvic dimension that can be measured clinically.
  • It is as shown and is the distance between the lower edge of the pubic symphysis to the sacral promontory
  • By subtracting 1.5 cm from the diagonal conjugate, we get the obstetric conjugate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 88, Textbook of Obstetrics, JB Sharma 3rd edition

questions.text: Match the following fetal head diameters with their numeric values:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-B, 2-D, 3-C, 4-A

 

Educational Objective:

 

DIAMETERS OF FETAL SKULL

 

 

 

Fig: The Important Landmarks of fetal skull

 

Ref: Page 91, JB Sharmas Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

questions.text:
Arrange the cardinal steps in the order they occur in mechanism of labor?

 

  1. Extension
  2. Engagement
  3. External rotation
  4. Internal rotation
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2,4,1,3

 

Mechanism of Labor (Cardinal steps) involve:

 

  1. Engagement
  2. Descent
  3. Flexion
  4. Internal Rotation
  5. Extension (Preceded by Crowning)
  6. Restitution
  7. External rotation
  8. Expulsion of body

 

Mnemonic: Every Damn Fool In Egypt Royally Eats Raw Eggs

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mechanism of Labor (Cardinal steps) involve:

 

  1. Engagement
  2. Descent
  3. Flexion
  4. Internal Rotation
  5. Extension (Preceded by Crowning)
  6. Restitution
  7. External rotation
  8. Expulsion of body

 

Mnemonic: Every Damn Fool In Egypt Royally Eats Raw Eggs

 

Ref: Page no 222, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: In Occipito-anterior position, the head is born by?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Extension

 

  • In occipito-anterior, the head is born by extension

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In occipito-anterior, the head is born by extension
  • In occipito-posterior, the head is born by face to pubes (There is initial flexion followed by extension)
  • In face presentation, the head is born by extension

 

Ref: Page no 222, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: When the anterior parietal bone of the fetus descends first into the pelvis during engagement, it is called?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Nagele’s asynclitism

 

  • Asynclitism is when the engagement is not symmetrical and one parietal bone enters the pelvic inlet first
  • Anterior asynclitism (Nagele’s asynclitism): When the anterior parietal bone enters 1st.
  • Posterior asynclitism (Litzman asynclitism): When the posterior parietal bone enters 1st (More common in Primigravidas)

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Asynclitism is when the engagement is not symmetrical and one parietal bone enters the pelvic inlet first
  • Anterior asynclitism (Nagele’s asynclitism): When the anterior parietal bone enters 1st.
  • Posterior asynclitism (Litzman asynclitism): When the posterior parietal bone enters 1st (More common in Primigravidas)

 

Ref: Page no 223, JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: When the largest transverse diameter of the fetal head, the bitemporal diameter enters the pelvic inlet
When the largest transverse diameter of the fetal head, the bitemporal diameter enters the pelvic mid cavity
When the largest transverse diameter of the fetal head, the biparietal diameter enters the pelvic inlet
When the largest transverse diameter of the fetal head, the biparietal diameter enters the pelvic mid cavity

questions.text: Engagement is defined as:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. When the largest transverse diameter of the fetal head, the biparietal diameter enters the pelvic inlet

 

  • The mechanism by which the biparietal diameter (The largest transverse diameter of the fetal head) passes through the pelvic inlet, is called engagement

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The mechanism by which the biparietal diameter (The largest transverse diameter of the fetal head) passes through the pelvic inlet, is called engagement

 

Ref: Page no 222, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma

choices.text: Rotation of the neck
Rotation of the shoulders
Untwisting of the neck
Untwisting of the shoulders

questions.text: External rotation occurs after the head is born. The head moves by 45˚and this occurs because?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Rotation of the shoulders

 

  • Once the head is born by extension, it is now free from the confines of the pelvis and untwists by 45˚ This untwisting of the neck is called as restitution.
  • Now the shoulders undergo internal rotation by 45˚ When the shoulders turn, the head automatically turns and this is visible as external rotation.
  • So external rotation is nothing but internal rotation of the shoulders

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The cardinal movement of external rotation is actually internal rotation of the shoulders

 

Ref: Page no 224, JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: Try to slip the cords over the fetal head
Deliver the anterior shoulder immediately
Clamp the cord, cut it and unwind it from around the fetal neck
Immediately call for help

questions.text: You are an intern and are conducting delivery of a 24y G2P1. The head is delivered and undergoes restitution and external rotation. When you attempt to deliver the anterior shoulder, you notice that there are 2 tight loops of cord around the neck. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Clamp the cord, cut it and unwind it from around the fetal neck

 

Remember in the scenario of loop(s) of cord around the neck, this is what is done.

 

  • If there is a loose loop(s) of cord around the neck, slip it over the neck
  • If there are tight loop (s) of cord around the neck, clamp the cord and unwind it over the neck

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remember in the scenario of loop(s) of cord around the neck, this is what is done.

 

  • If there is a loose loop(s) of cord around the neck, slip it over the neck
  • If there are tight loop (s) of cord around the neck, clamp the cord and unwind it over the neck

 

Ref: Page no 224, JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: Meeting of suture lines
Reducible overlap of suture lines
Irreducible overlap of suture lines
Scalp edema with irreducible overlap of suture lines

questions.text: Grade 2 moulding means?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Reducible overlap of suture lines

 

  • Moulding is a feature of the fetal head which help it negotiate its way through the pelvis.
  • Grades of moulding
    1. Grade 0: No moulding
    2. Grade 1: Meeting of suture lines
    3. Grade 2: Reducible overlap of suture lines
    4. Grade 3: Irreducible overlap of suture lines

 

Educational Objective:

 

Grades of moulding

 

  • Grade 0: No moulding
  • Grade 1: Meeting of suture lines
  • Grade 2: Reducible overlap of suture lines
  • Grade 3: Irreducible overlap of suture lines (sign of obstructed labor)

 

Ref: Page no 224, JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: A primigravida at 38 weeks with Rh negative pregnancy with ICT negative
A G2A1 at 37 weeks with preeclampsia
39y primigravida at 34 weeks with FGR and absent end diastolic flow in umbilical artery

questions.text: Which is Not an indication for induction of labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A primigravida at 38 weeks with Rh negative pregnancy with ICT negative

 

Let’s discuss all the options:

 

Option A. A primigravida at 38 weeks with Rh negative pregnancy with ICT negative: Rh negative pregnancy (not iso-immunized) should not go beyond 40 weeks and is an indication or induction of labor at 40 weeks.

 

Option B. A G2A1 at 37 weeks with preeclampsia: Preeclampsia: mild – deliver at 37 weeks/ severe – deliver at 34 weeks or earlier

 

Option C. 39y primigravida at 34 weeks with FGR and absent end diastolic flow in umbilical artery: Fetal growth restriction: Delivery at 37 weeks if mild/ if absent or reversal of diastolic flow in umbilical artery – Deliver immediately

 

Option D.  22y old G2 at 41 weeks: Post datism: As per ACOG, induction should be offered at 41 weeks

 

Educational Objective:

 

A pregnant woman with an Rh-negative blood group with a negative ICT (not iso-immunized) should not be allowed to go beyond 40 weeks, i.e. if she doesn’t go into labor, she should be induced at 40 weeks. This is to reduce the risk of feto-maternal hemorrhage.

 

Ref: Page no 246, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

choices.text: She will not respond favorably to induction of labor and will require pre-induction cervical ripening
She will not respond favorably to induction and LSCS should be done
She will respond favorably to induction of labor
The given information is insufficient to make a conclusion

questions.text: A 32-year G2 presents to the antenatal OPD. Her period of gestation is 40 weeks. She is planned for induction of labor. On a vaginal exam, the cervix is 2 cm dilated, 1 cm long, soft inconsistency and mid-position. The station of the fetal head is at -1. She asks if induction of labor will be successful? What will you tell her?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. She will respond favorably to induction of labor

 

  • Bishop’s score is a scoring system used to assess the favorability of the cervix to respond to induction of labor.
  • In this patient, the Bishop score is 8 (As seen from the Bishop score below)
  • A Bishop score > 6 is favourable i.e. she will respond favorably to induction of labor

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Bishop score is as shown in the table.
  • Each component is scored from 0 to 3
  • The highest score is 13 and the lowest is 0
  • A favourable score is > 6. This means the patient will respond favorably to methods of induction of labor.

 

 

Ref: Page no 247, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

choices.text: Position of the cervix
Station of the fetal head
Position of the fetal head

questions.text: Which is NOT a component of the Modified Bishop score?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Position of the fetal head

 

  • The Modified Bishop score has the following components
    1. Effacement
    2. Cervical dilatation
    3. Position of the cervix
    4. Consistency of the cervix
    5. Station of the head
  • Mnemonic: BISHOP
    • B – Bishop stands for
      • I – Effacement
      • S – Station
      • H – Hard/ soft (Consistency)
      • O – Os open (dilatation)
      • P – Position of cervix

 

Thus, option D) Position of fetal head is not a component of BPP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Modified Bishop score has the following components
    1. Effacement
    2. Cervical dilatation
    3. Position of the cervix
    4. Consistency of the cervix
    5. Station of the head
  • Mnemonic: BISHOP
    • B – Bishop stands for
      • I – Effacement
      • S – Station
      • H – Hard/ soft (Consistency)
      • O – Os open (dilatation)
      • P – Position of cervix

 

Ref: Page no 247, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

questions.text: A 24-year primi is undergoing induction of labor for past dates. Her Bishop score is 1. Which would not be a preferred method?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Artificial rupture of membranes

 

Let’s discuss all the options:

 

Option A: PGE2 intracervical gel: This is a common method of induction of labor and can be used in the scenario given

 

Option B: PGE1 vaginal tablet: This is also a method of induction of labor and can be used in low doses (25 mcg)

 

Option C: Inj Oxytocin: Oxytocin is also used in induction of labor. Although it is prefered for augmentation of labour than induction of labour 

 

Option D: Remember for doing an Artificial rupture of membranes: the cervix requires to be dilated by at least 3 cm.  In the scenario given the Bishop score is 1, which means the cervix is likely to be closed

 

Thus, answer is D) artificial rupture of membranes which will not be possible in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Methods of induction of labor
    • Medical
      • PGE1, PGE2, Oxytocin
    • Surgical
      • Sweeping of membranes
      • Artificial rupture of membranes
    • Mechanical
      • Dilators (like laminaria tents)
      • Foley’s catheter

 

Ref: Page no 251, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma 3rd edition

questions.text: Uterine tachysystole is a complication of induction of labor. This means the uterus is excessively contracting > …….. times in 10 minutes
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 5

 

  • Uterine tachysystole is presence of more than 5 contractions  in 10 minutes
  • Uterine hyperstimulation is Uterine tachysystole with non-reassuring fetal status

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Uterine tachysystole is presence of more than 5 contractions  in 10 minutes
  • Uterine hyperstimulation is Uterine tachysystole with non-reassuring fetal status

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition page480.

choices.text: Maintain continuous deflexion of head
Episiotomy should be performed as a routine
A warm cloth should be applied to the perineum to prevent trauma
Delivery should be ideally performed in a lithotomy position

questions.text: According to WHO guidelines on management of labor, which of the following is true about management of second stage of labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A warm cloth should be applied to the perineum to prevent trauma

 

Let’s Discuss all the options

 

  • Option A: Maintaining deflexion of the head is not recommended. The head should be delivered by controlled extension in the 2nd stage of labor
  • Option B: Episiotomy should be restrictively used only when necessary and not routinely
  • Option C: A warm cloth should be applied to the perineum to prevent trauma. This is true. The following are recommended to prevent perineal trauma during the 2nd stage
    • Warm compress
    • Perineal massage
    • Perineal support
  • Option D: Delivery should be ideally performed in the position the patient prefers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As per WHO recommendations of 2018,

 

As per WHO guidelines on intrapartum care for a positive birth experience (2018), these are the recommendations in 2nd stage

 

  1. Definition and duration of the second stage of labor:
    • The second stage is the period of time between full cervical dilatation and birth of the baby, during which the woman has an involuntary urge to bear down, as a result of expulsive uterine contractions.
    • In first labors, birth is usually completed within 3 hours whereas in subsequent labors, birth is usually completed within 2 hours.
  2. Recommended Birth position (for women with or without epidural analgesia)
    •  For women without epidural analgesia, encouraging the adoption of a birth position of the individual woman’s choice, including upright positions, is recommended.
  3. Method of pushing    
    •  Women in the expulsive phase of the second stage of labor should be encouraged and supported to follow their own urge to push.
  4. Method of pushing (for women with epidural analgesia)
    • For women with epidural analgesia in the second stage of labor, delaying pushing for one to two hours after full dilatation or until the woman regains the sensory urge to bear down is recommended in the context where resources are available for longer stay in second stage and perinatal hypoxia can be adequately assessed and managed.
  5. Techniques for preventing perineal trauma.
    • For women in the second stage of labor, techniques to reduce perineal trauma and facilitate spontaneous birth (including perineal massage, warm compresses and a “hands on” guarding of the perineum) are recommended, based on a woman’s preferences and available options.
  6.  Episiotomy policy
    • Routine or liberal use of episiotomy is not recommended for women undergoing spontaneous vaginal birth.
  7. Fundal pressure
    •  Application of manual fundal pressure to facilitate childbirth during the second stage of labor is not recommended.

 

In brief in 2nd stage of labor (WHO guidelines 2018)

 

Recommended

 

  • Duration of 2nd stage in primi – 3h, multi – 2h
  • Birthing position of choice
  • Encouraged to follow their own urge to push
  • Reduce perineal trauma by – hands on guarding/ warm compress/ perineal massage

 

Not recommended

 

  • Routine episiotomy
  • Fundal pressure

 

Ref: WHO recommendations: Intrapartum care for a positive childbirth experience (Feb 2018)

questions.text: A midwife at a PHC is monitoring pregnancy and maintaining the WHO modified partograph of pregnancy progression. At how much cervical dilation should the partograph plotting be started?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 4 cm

 

Partograph

 

  • Partograph is a graphical representation of progress of labor, which is depicted using cervical dilatation and descent of head against the duration of labor.
  • It is used for early detection of abnormal labor patterns for timely intervention.
  • In a partograph the active phase of labor starts when the cervix is 4 cm dilated.
  • In active phase, cervix should dilate at the rate of 1 cm/hr.  (Alert Line)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Partograph is a graphical representation of progress of labor, which is depicted using cervical dilatation and descent of head against the duration of labor.
  • It is used for early detection of abnormal labor patterns for timely intervention.
  • In a partograph the active phase of labor starts when the cervix is 4 cm dilated.
  • In active phase, cervix should dilate at the rate of 1 cm/hr.  (Alert Line)
  • Partograph has two lines for assessment of progression of dilation
    1. Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate)
    2. Action line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.

 

 

  • Remember that in the modified partograph, plotting starts at 4 cm onward, and the 1st mark is always put on the alert line
  • If asked, when does plotting start in the Labor care guide (Next generation partograph), then the answer is 5cm

 

Ref: Page no 212, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma 3rd edition

choices.text: 1 cm above the ischial spine
1 cm below the ischial spine
At the level of ischial spine
1 cm below the cervical os

questions.text: A midwife at a PHC did per vaginal examination of a women in labor with 8 cm cervical dilation and 70% cervical effacement with the fetal head at +1 station. This +1 station implies the position of fetal head is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1 cm below the ischial spine

 

Station describes descent of the fetal presenting part in relation to a line drawn between maternal ischial spines. Thus +1 station implies fetal head is 1 cm below the ischial spine.

 

  • When the lowermost portion of the presenting fetal part is at the level of the spines, it is designated as being at zero (O) station.
  • In 1989, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists adopted the classification of station that divides the pelvis above and below the spines into fifths. Each fifth represents 1 cm above or below the spines.
  • Thus, as the presenting fetal part descends from the inlet toward the ischial spines, the designation is —5,—4,—3,—2,—1, then O station.
    Below the spines, as the presenting fetal part descends, it passes +1, +2, +3, +4, and +5 stations to delivery.
  • If the leading part of the fetal head is at O station or below, most often the fetal head has engaged.
  • In the UK, the system of thirds is followed (-3,-2,-1,0,+1,+2,+3)

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 220, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma 3rd edition

choices.text: Uterotonic agent within 1 minute of birth

questions.text: All are components of active management of the third stage of labor except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Early cord clamping

 

Main components of 3rd stage of labor are

 

  • Administering a uterotonic
  • Controlled cord traction
  • Assessment of uterine tone

 

Educational Objective:

 

Active Management of 3rd Stage of Labor

 

  • Described by the WHO in 2007
  • Involves mainly 3 basic steps.
    • Administering a uterotonic
    • Controlled cord traction
    • Uterine massage
  • AMTSL prevents atonic PPH.
  • In 2012, the WHO issued new guidelines for AMTSL which essentially emphasized the main 3 things but with additional information which was
    • Oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice for AMTSL (10 IU IM/IV)
    • Do Controlled cord traction only if a skilled birth attendant is present.
    • Sustained uterine massage is not recommended for all women who’ve received uterotonic; instead; postpartum uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is done.
    • Delayed cord clamping (performed after 1 to 3 minutes after birth) is recommended for all births while initiating simultaneous essential newborn care (This is not to prevent atonic PPH but was introduced along with AMTSL to ensure it is followed)
  • In 2018, the WHO issued further guidelines on which other uterotonics can be used for AMTSL. These include:
    • Oxytocin (10 IU IM/IV)
    • Carbetocin (100 mcg IM/IV)
    • Misoprostol (400 OR 600 mcg PO – to be used where Skilled birth attendant isn’t available)
    • Ergometrine/methylergometrine (200 mcg IV EXCEPT in hypertensive women))
    • Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination (5 IU/500 µg, IM)
  • Injectable prostaglandins (carboprost or sulprostone) are not recommended for the prevention of PPH
  • AMTSL decreases
    • Incidence of PPH.
    • Length of third stage of labor.
    • Percentage of third stages of labor lasting longer than 30 minutes.
    • Need for blood transfusion.
    • Need for uterotonic drugs to manage PPH

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition pg 438

choices.text: Secondary arrest after progression of labor
Prolonged active phase of labor
Prolonged latent phase/primary arrest of labor
Normal labor in a primigravida

questions.text: The following graph represents the stages of labor. Which of the following statements is true about graph C?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Secondary arrest after progression of labor

 

  • Graph C shows progress of labor followed by a plateau. This plateau is a stall in the progress of labor and is referred to as arrest of cervical dilatation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 272, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

questions.text: Mrs. Shiny, a G2P1L1 presented to the hospital in labor pains. On examination she had 3 uterine contractions of 20 seconds in 10 minutes, Cervical dilation was 6 cm and HR 145 bpm. What is the stage of labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Stage I

 

Stages 1 of labor is from the onset of true labor pains to full dilatation of the cervix.

 

Other Options

 

  • Stage 2 of labor is from full dilatation of the cervix to delivery of the baby
  • Stage 3 of labor is from delivery of the baby to delivery of the placenta
  • Stage 4 of labor is from delivery of the placenta to an hour of observation post delivery

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal Labor

 

Uterine contractions which bring about cervical effacement and dilatation.

 

Stage 1:

 

  • From 0 cm to 10 cm dilatation
  • Divided into latent phase and active phase.
  • Latent phase: The point at which mother perceives regular contractions.
  • Active phase: Cervical dilatation of
    • 4cm (as per the WHO modified partograph)
    • 5 cm (As per the new WHO labor care guide)
    • 6 cm (As per ACOG).

 

Stage 2:

 

  • Complete cervical dilatation with active expulsive efforts by the mother

 

Stage 3:

 

  • Delivery of placenta and membranes

 

Stage 4:

 

  • “The Golden hour”
  • One hour after delivery of baby. The mother should be monitored for signs of post-partum hemorrhage.

 

Ref: Page no 227, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Episiotomy scissor

 

It is a Braun episiotomy scissors. It is non-ratcheted finger ring scissors, angled with smooth, blunt tips, and has a length of 5-1/2 inches.

 

Other Options

 

  • Babcock’s forceps

 

 

Finger ring ratcheted ,non perforating forceps used to grasp tubular and delicate structures

 

  • Ovum forceps:

 

 

They don’t have lock, used to remove retained products of conception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

This is a Braun episiotomy scissors. It is non-ratcheted finger ring scissors, angled with smooth, blunt tips, and has a length of 5-1/2 inches.

 

Ref:  Page no 713, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma 3rd edition

questions.text: A 24-year-old G2P1 woman at 39 weeks’ gestation presents with painful uterine contractions. She also complains of minimal vaginal blood mixed with some mucus. Which of the following describes the most likely etiology of her bleeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Bloody show

 

  • Bloody show or loss of the cervical mucus plug is often a sign of impending labor.
  •  The sticky mucus admixed with blood can differentiate bloody show from antepartum bleeding. The blood is due to rupture of capillaries during cervical dilatation

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Placenta previa: It is unlikely to be abruption as although there is pain, it mentions there are contractions, so this is likely labor related. Also there is mucus mixed with it.
  • Option B. Placenta abruption: Placenta previa is usually painless, and the bleed is excessive
  • Option D. Vasa previa: usually presents at membrane rupture and the bleeding is excessive

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bloody show or loss of the cervical mucus plug is often a sign of impending labor.
  •  The sticky mucus admixed with blood can differentiate bloody show from antepartum bleeding. The blood is due to rupture of capillaries during cervical dilatation

 

Ref: Page no 212, Textbook of Obstetrics by Dr JB Sharma, 3rd edition

choices.text: Progressive cervical dilation and effacement
Rupture of membranes
Relief on sedation and NSAIDs
Formation of bag of waters

questions.text: Which of the following is the best parameter to differentiate between true and false labour pains?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Progressive cervical dilation and effacement

 

The best parameter used to differentiate between true and false labor pains is cervical dilatation and effacement

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 212, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma 3rd edition

choices.text: New generation partograph
Next generation partograph
Newest generation partograph

questions.text: The WHO Labor Care Guide is the?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Next generation partograph

 

The WHO Labor care guide is also called the next generation partograph

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 213 JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: Alert and action lines are separated by a difference of 4 hours
Partograph recording should be started at a cervical dilation of 4 cm
Send the patient to first referral unit if the labor progression line crosses the alert line

questions.text: Partograph represents various stages of labor with respect to time. Which is incorrect regarding the WHO modified partograph?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Each small square represents one hour

 

Let’s discuss all the options

 

  • Option A: Each small square represents one hour: This is incorrect, each large square represents 1 hour, and the small square is half an hour
  • Option B: Alert and action lines are separated by a difference of 4 hours. This is a correct statement; the alert line is plotted @1cm/h; the action line is plotted after 4 hours.
  • Option C: Partograph recording should be started at a cervical dilation of 4 cm. This is also a correct statement.
  • Option D: Send the patient to first referral unit if the labor progression line crosses the alert line. Once the alert line is crossed, the patient should be referred to a place with emergency obstetric care facility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Partograph 

 

  • The WHO modified Partograph is a graphical representation of progress of labour, which is depicted using cervical dilatation and descent of head against the duration of labour. 
  • It is used for early detection of abnormal labour patterns for timely intervention. 
  • In a partograph the active phase of labour starts when the cervix is 4 cm dilated. In active phase, cervix should dilate at the rate of 1 cm/hr. 
  • Partograph has two lines for assessment of progression of dilation. 
    • Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate)
    • Action line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention. 

 

Ref: Page no 213 JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

questions.text: A 30y old G2 presents in active labor at 9 am. She is 6 cm dilated, well effaced with the Vertex at -1 station. Accordingly, a modified WHO partograph is plotted. At what time do you expect her to be fully dilated according to this partograph?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1 pm

 

  • If we follow the WHO modified partograph, she should be dilating @1cm/h after 4cm
  • So if she 6cm at 9am, she will be 10 cm after 4hours i.e. at 1 pm

 

Educational Objective:

 

As per the WHO modified partograph, cervical dilatation should happen @1cm/h

 

Ref: Page no 213 JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: The head got engaged at 8 am
She was in 2nd stage at 1 pm
Her cervical dilatation is normal
At full dilatation, the head is not palpable per abdomen

questions.text: See the WHO modified partograph filled below. Plotting was started at 8 am when she was 5 cm dilated. Which is incorrect regarding interpretation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The head got engaged at 8 am

 

  • At 8 am, the cervix is 5 cm dilated and the head is 4/5th palpable per abdomen
  • 4/5th palpable per abdomen is not engagement. Engagement happens when the head is 1/5th palpable. This happened after 4 hours (12 noon)
  • i.e. After 4 hours (At 12), the cervix is 9 cm dilated (appropriate) and the head is 1/5th palpable (engaged)
  • At 1 o’clock (After 5 hours), she is fully dilated and the head is 0/5th palpable (i.e., fetal head is not palpable on abdominal exam)

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B: She was in 2nd stage at 1 pm: This is correct as she was fully dilated at 1pm
  • Option C: Her cervical dilatation is normal: This is correct as it follows the alert line @1cm/h
  • Option D: At full dilatation, the head is not palpable per abdomen: This is also correct as at this dilatation the head is 0/5th palpable i.e. not palpable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The descent of the fetal head on the partograph is plotted as per fifths of head palpable.
  • When the head is 1/5th palpable, the station is at 0 station and the head is said to be engaged.

 

Ref: Page no 212 JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

questions.text: Following delivery of a 4kg baby to a mother with gestational diabetes, you note that there is a tear involving the perineum and external anal sphincter with intact mucosa. The grade of the tear is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Third degree

 

Classification of Obstetric Anal Sphincter Injury

 

Explanation and Other Options

 

  • First degree:  Injury to perineal skin
  • Second degree: Injury to perineum involving perineal body (muscles) but not involving the anal sphincter.
  • Third degree: Injury to perineum, involving the anal sphincter complex (both the external and internal).
    • 3a: if half thickness external anal sphincter involved.
    • 3b: if full thickness external anal sphincter involved.
    • 3c: if internal anal sphincter involved.
  • Fourth degree: Injury to perineum involving the anal sphincter complex (external anal sphincter and internal anal sphincter) and anal epithelium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 1311, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman in labor presents with an occiput posterior position. What is a potential maternal complaint commonly associated with it?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Back pain

 

Explanation: An occiput posterior position is associated with severe back labor pain due to the fetal occiput pressing against the maternal sacrum.

 

This is the most common complaint associated with the occiput posterior position. The back of the baby's head pressing against the mother's sacrum can cause intense lower back pain, often referred to as "back labor." This pain can persist throughout labor and is often exacerbated during contractions.

 

Other Options: 

 

  • Option B: While abdominal pain is common during labor regardless of the fetal position, the OP position does not specifically cause more severe abdominal pain than other positions. However, labor might be longer and more painful overall due to the suboptimal alignment of the baby's head with the maternal pelvis.
  • Option C: Frequent urination is a common symptom of occipitoposterior
  • Option D: Shoulder pain or discomfort during pregnancy might be related to changes in posture, stress on the spine, or could be referred pain from gallbladder issues, which can be more common in pregnancy, but it's not a symptom commonly linked to fetal position in labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clinical features of Occipito posterior

 

Symptoms:

 

  • Backache
  • PROM
  • Frequency of micturition
  • Delayed engagement
  • Prolonged labor

 

Abdominal exam:

 

  • Sub-umbilical flattening
  • Pelvic grip: Head is deflexed (Both sinciput and occiput felt at same level)
  • Auscultation: fetal heart heard at flanks

 

 

  • Per vaginal exam
    • In a well flexed head, the anterior fontanelle cannot be palpated, but if you are able to palpate the fontanelle, that means the head is deflexed which is common in OP

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition pg 425

questions.text: A 24 years primigravida presents in early labor. On abdominal examination, there is sub-umbilical flattening and on palpation, the fetus is in longitudinal lie, cephalic presentation with the head high and both sinciput and occiput felt at the same level. The fetal heart is auscultated at the flanks. What is the most likely abnormality?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Occipito-posterior

 

This is most likely an occipito-posterior position. 

 

The typical examination findings on abdominal examination in occipito-posterior are: 

 

  • Subumbilical flattening
  • Pelvic grip: Head is deflexed (Both sinciput and occiput felt at same level)
  • Auscultation: fetal heart heard at flanks

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Occipito-transverse: On abdominal examination, the back will be on the lateral aspect and hence there will not be any subumbilical flattening. The fetal heart however may be better felt at the flanks. 

 

Option C: Face presentation: On abdominal exam, the typical finding is the sinciput and the back are on the same side (normally in flexed positions, the sinciput and back will be on opposite sides). A groove is felt between the back and the head. 

 

Option D: On abdominal exam, the head is unengaged, a groove is felt between the back and the occiput and the sinciput and the back are on the same side as in face presentation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Occipito-Posterior Position

 

Risk Factors

 

  • Anthropoid pelvis
  • Android pelvis (less common)
  • Anterior placenta
  • CPD
  • Deflexed head

 

Diagnosis

 

Abdominal exam:

 

  • Sub-umbilical flattening
  • Pelvic grip: Head is deflexed (Both sinciput and occiput felt at same level)
  • Auscultation: fetal heart heard at flanks

 

Per vaginal exam

 

  • In a well flexed head, the anterior fontanelle cannot be palpated, but if you are able to palpate the fontanelle, that means the head is deflexed which is common in OP

 

Ref: Page no 302, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

choices.text: Extension at hip joint, flexion at knee joint
Flexion at hip joint, extension at knee joint
Flexion at both hip and knee joint
Extension at both hip and knee joint

questions.text: A 30yr primi is diagnosed with Frank breech. Which statement is true about frank breech?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Flexion at hip joint, extension at knee joint

 

In a Frank Breech, there is flexion at the hip joint and extension at the knee joint

 

Educational Objective: 

 

 

  • Extended Breech (Frank breech): Flexion at hip joint, Extension at knee joint
  • Flexed Breech (Complete breech): Flexion at hip joint, flexion at knee joint
  • Footling breech: Extension at hip and knee joint
  • Kneeling breech: Extension at hip joint, flexion at knee joint 

 

Ref: Page no 322 JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: Await spontaneous onset of labor and normal vaginal delivery
Perform a cesarean section, if labor becomes prolonged

questions.text: A 40yr primi presents to the antenatal clinic at 38 weeks. On examination, the fetus is in breech presentation. The estimated fetal weight is 3 kg. On pelvic examination, the cervix is closed, 3 cm long, soft and posterior. The breech is high up. The pelvis appears adequate. The best management option is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Perform cesarean section at 39 weeks.

 

  • The best answer would be to perform a cesarean at 39 weeks as she is not very favourable for an assisted breech delivery. Rememebr primi brrech is usually a direct indication for a cesarean section. 

 

 

  • In this patient as points against a successful delivery are:
    • Primi
    • Poor Bishop score
    • High station

Inclusion Criteria for Planned Vaginal Breech Delivery:

 

  • Gestational age ≥ 37 weeks
  • Frank or complete breech presentation
  • No fetal anomalies
  • Adequate maternal pelvis
  • Estimated fetal weight between 2,500–4,000 g
  • Normal amniotic fluid volume (≥3 cm vertical pocket)
  • Documented flexed fetal head
  • No contraindication to vaginal birth
  • Continuous fetal monitoring must be available

 

Contraindications to Vaginal Breech Delivery:

 

  • Footling breech
  • Hyperextended fetal head
  • Inadequate pelvis
  • Estimated fetal weight <2,500 g or >4,000 g
  • Suspected fetal compromise or anomalies

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Await spontaneous onset of labor and normal vaginal delivery: A cesarean delivery would be more favourable for this patient as there is a high chance of the aftercoming head of breech getting stuck in this patient.

 

Option C. Perform a cesarean if labor is prolonged: An elective cesarean is better in this patient as she is not favourable for an assisted breech delivery. 

 

Option D. Perform an external cephalic version: External cephalic version is best attempted at 36-37 weeks and shpuld not be done now at 39 weeks as the failure rate is higher and it is more difficult to do. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • This is the Zatuchni Andros Score for breech delivery. A score of 3 or less, cesarean is preferred

 

 

Ref: Page no 329  JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

questions.text: Best method to deliver nuchal arms in breech?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lovset’s method

 

Lovsets manuever is used in delivery of nuchal arms while conducting an assisted breech delivery. 

 

Other Options

 

  • Option B: Smellie-Viet: This maneuver is used to deliver the aftercoming head in a breech delivery
  • Option C: Pinard maneuver: This is used to deliver the legs expecially in a total breech extraction
  • Option D: Ritgen's maneuver: This maneuver is used in cephalic presentation and is controleld extension of the head int he 2nd stage of laboe

 

Educational Objective:

 

Assisted Breech Delivery:

 

  • In breech delivery assistance may be required for:
  1. Delivery of head 
    •  Burns-Marshall method
    • Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit method
    • Piper’s forceps or Neville-Barnes forceps
       
  2. Extended legs 
    • Pinard’s maneuver (Remember: P for popliteal fossa and P for Pinard maneuver)
  3. Extended arm
  • Lovset’s maneuver

 

Sometimes the head rotates posteriorly, so that the face is behind the pubis. Delivery in this position is difficult and ‘Prague maneuver’ may be tried.

  • Best time for episiotomy in breech
    Climbing of perineum.
  • Best time for episiotomy in vertex
    Crowning of head.

 

Ref: Page no 329  JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition.

choices.text: Reposit the hand back and external version
Reposit the hand back and internal version

questions.text: A 32yr G2P1 is referred at her 36 weeks from the primary health center with prolonged labor. On examination, the patient is dehydrated. Abdominal examination reveals a 32 weeks uterus which is tonically contracted. The presentation is unclear. Fetal heart rate is absent. On local examination, the hand is seen outside the introitus. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cesarean section

 

  • This is a case of hand prolapse with neglected shoulder presentation.
  • The patient is in obstructed labor
  • The best management option is an emergency LSCS (even for a dead fetus)
  • Post LSCS, the catheter should be kept for a minimum of 2 weeks to allow bladder healing and prevent VVF formation

 

Ref: Page 1129, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 25y woman presents at 37 weeks in early labor. After a few hours, the patient complains of leaking per vaginum. The CTG shows a prolonged deceleration and on vaginal examination, the cord is felt in the vagina. The cervix is 8cm dilated. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lift the presenting part up

 

  • This is cord prolapse
  • IT is an obstetric emergency
  • The cord can get compressed between the presenting part and maternal bony pelvis leading to fetal hypoxia and death
  • Immediate urgent LSCS is the rule if the fetus is alive.
  • Whilst preparing for the cesarean section, the pressure needs to be relieved off the cord. This can be done by
  • Lifting the presenting part off the cord
  • Filling the bladder with urine
  • Positioning the patient to help relieve pressure off the cord: Trendelenburg position/ Left lateral position/ All 4 positions.
  • Remember: Do not handle the cord or try to reposit it. Handling the cord leads to vasospasm

 

Ref: Page 1129, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: Match the maneuver used in shoulder dystocia with the description:
questions.solution:
Ans: D. a-4, b-2, c-3, d-1

 

  • Shoulder dystocia is when the head delivers but the shoulders fail to deliver even after 1 minute of delivery of the head

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shoulder Dystocia Maneuvers

 

  1. McRoberts maneuver: -  
    • Hyperflexion of mother’s legs onto the abdomen during child birth
    • This widens the pelvis, and flattens the lumbar spine.
  2. Suprapubic pressure: 
    • directional (45° downward) pressure to the maternal abdomen just above the pubic symphysis.
    • This pressure should be applied to the posterior aspect of the anterior shoulder, pushing toward the opposite side from where the attendant is positioned.
    • Suprapubic pressure is often used concomitantly with the McRoberts maneuver.
  3. Rubin II or posterior pressure on the anterior shoulder, which would bring the fetus in an oblique position with head somewhat towards the vagina
  4. Woods’ screw maneuver which leads to turning the anterior shoulder to the posterior and vice versa (somewhat the opposite of Rubin II maneuver)
  5. Gaskin maneuver involves moving the mother to an all fours position with the back arched, widening the pelvic outlet.
  6. Zaninelli’s maneuver, which involves pushing the fetal head back in with performing a cesarean section. or internal cephalic replacement followed by Cesarean section.
  7.  Intentional fetal clavicular fracture, which reduces the diameter of the shoulder girdle that requires to pass through the birth canal.
  8. Maternal symphysiotomy, which makes the opening of the birth canal laxer by breaking the connective tissue between the two pubes bones facilitating the passage of the shoulders.
  9. Abdominal rescue, described by O’Shaughnessy. where a hysterotomy facilitates vaginal delivery of the impacted shoulder

 

ReF: Page no 1288, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

choices.text: Anterior rotation of the symphysis pubis
Displaces the fetal shoulder axis from anterior posterior (AP) to oblique

questions.text: A 24 - year primi presents in active labor at 40 weeks’ gestation. Delivery of the fetal head occurs, but the fetal shoulders do not deliver despite several attempts. To resolve it, McRoberts maneuver was done. Which of the following describes this maneuver?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anterior rotation of the symphysis pubis 

 

  • Shoulder dystocia is when the head delivers but the shoulders fail to deliver even after 1 minute of delivery of the head
  • The most important and first maneuver done in this scenario is the McRoberts maneuver where the legs are hyperflexed and abducted over the maternal abdomen. 
  • This results in widening of the pelvis as the spine is flattened posteriorly and the pubic symphysis is rotated anteriorly. 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Decreasing the fetal bi-acromial diameter: This happens in the Rubin maneuver where the arm is adducted to the chest thereby reducing the bi-acromial diameter

 

Option C. Separates the maternal symphysis pubis: This does not happen in McRobert's maneuver. In a symphysiotomy, the pubic symphysis is cut/ seperated

 

Option D. Displaces the fetal shoulder axis from anterior posterior (AP) to oblique: This is the mechanism of action in Wood's corkscrew maneuver

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shoulder Dystocia Maneuvers

 

  1. McRoberts maneuver: -  
    • Hyperflexion of mother’s legs onto the abdomen during child birth
    • This widens the pelvis, and flattens the lumbar spine.
  2. Suprapubic pressure: 
    • Directional (45° downward) pressure to the maternal abdomen just above the pubic symphysis.
    • This pressure should be applied to the posterior aspect of the anterior shoulder, pushing toward the opposite side from where the attendant is positioned.
    • Suprapubic pressure is often used concomitantly with the McRoberts maneuver.
  3. Rubin II or posterior pressure on the anterior shoulder, which would bring the fetus in an oblique position with head somewhat towards the vagina
  4. Woods’ screw maneuver which leads to turning the anterior shoulder to the posterior and vice versa (somewhat the opposite of Rubin II maneuver)
  5. Gaskin maneuver involves moving the mother to an all fours position with the back arched, widening the pelvic outlet.
  6. Zaninelli’s maneuver, which involves pushing the fetal head back in with performing a cesarean section. or internal cephalic replacement followed by Cesarean section.
  7.  Intentional fetal clavicular fracture, which reduces the diameter of the shoulder girdle that requires to pass through the birth canal.
  8. Maternal symphysiotomy, which makes the opening of the birth canal laxer by breaking the connective tissue between the two pubes bones facilitating the passage of the shoulders.
  9. Abdominal rescue, described by O’Shaughnessy. where a hysterotomy facilitates vaginal delivery of the impacted shoulder

 

 Ref: Page no 1288, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman is in labor, and shoulder dystocia is suspected. Which maternal maneuver is often recommended as a first-line intervention to alleviate shoulder dystocia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. McRoberts maneuver

 

Explanation: 

 

The McRoberts maneuver involves hyper-flexing the mother's thighs to the abdomen, which helps to reposition the baby's shoulders and alleviate shoulder dystocia.

 

Shoulder Dystocia Maneuvers

 

  • McRoberts maneuver: -  
    • Hyperflexion of mother’s legs onto the abdomen during child birth
    • This widens the pelvis and flattens the lumbar spine.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Suprapubic pressure: 
    • This pressure should be applied to the posterior aspect of the anterior shoulder, pushing toward the opposite side from where the attendant is positioned.
    • Suprapubic pressure is often used concomitantly with the McRoberts maneuver.
  • Rubin II or posterior pressure on the anterior shoulder, which would bring the fetus in an oblique position with head somewhat towards the vagina
  • Woods’ screw maneuver which leads to turning the anterior shoulder to the posterior and vice versa
  • Gaskin maneuver involves moving the mother to an all-fours position with the back arched, widening the pelvic outlet.
  • Zavanelli maneuver, which involves pushing the fetal head back in with performing a cesarean section. or internal cephalic replacement followed by Cesarean section.
  • Intentional fetal clavicular fracture, which reduces the diameter of the shoulder girdle that is required to pass through the birth canal.
  • Maternal symphysiotomy, which makes the opening of the birth canal laxer by breaking the connective tissue between the two pubes bones facilitating the passage of the shoulders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remember the HELPERR to remember management of shoulder dystocia

 

H: Call for HELP

 

E: Episiotomy

 

L: Legs: McRobert Manuever

 

P: Supra-pubic pressure

 

E: Enter the Rotational maneuvers

 

R: Remove the posterior arm

 

R: Roll the patient on all 4s

 

Also remember

 

  • Zavanelli maneuver: Push the head back in and deliver by cesarean
  • Destructive surgeries
    • Cleidotomy: Deliberate fracture of the clavicle
    • Symphysiotomy: Deliberate fracture of the pubic symphysis

 

Ref: Page no 1288, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

questions.text: All are risk factors for shoulder dystocia except?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Primigravida

 

Primigravid women are NOT at a higher risk for hsoulder dystocia

 

Let's Discuss the other Options:

 

  • Option A: Previous h/o shoulder dystocia: This increases the risk of a repeat shoulder dystocia
  • Option B: Multiparity: Multiparous women are at a higher risk of shoulder dystocia. This could be as the weight of the fetus tends to increase with every pregnancy
  • Option D: Vacuum delivery: This also increases the risk of shoulder dytocia

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Risk factors for shoulder dystocia include

 

  1. Previous shoulder dystocia
  2. Macrosomia
  3. Diabetes
  4. Obesity
  5. Induced labor
  6. Prolonged labor
  7. Vacuum and forceps (more common with vacuum)
  8. Anencephaly
  9. Multiparity
  10. Post maturity

 

ReF: Page no 469, DC Duttas textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman who is otherwise healthy, has an uneventful vaginal delivery of a full-term infant. One day postpartum, she complains of visual changes and a severe headache. Two hours after this, she is found unresponsive and profoundly hypotensive. She is intubated and put on mechanical ventilation. Her BP is 68/28 mmHg. Heart rate is 140 bp. O2 saturation is 95% on FiO2 of 0.40. Physical exam is unremarkable. Lab tests are notable for glucose of 48 mg/ dl with a normal hematocrit and TLC. Which of the following will reverse her hypotension?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hydrocortisone

 

  • This patient has evidence of Sheehan syndrome after giving birth.
  • In this syndrome, the postpartum hypoplastic pituitary is at increased risk for hemorrhage and/or infarction. This leads to bilateral visual changes, headache, and meningeal signs.
  • In severe cases, cardiovascular collapse and altered levels of consciousness may be observed.
  • Laboratory evaluation commonly shows hypoglycemia.
  • Pituitary computed tomography (CT) or MRI may show signs of sellar hemorrhage if present. Involvement of all pituitary hormones may be seen, although the most acute findings are often hypoglycemia and hypotension from failure of ACTH.
  • The hypoglycemia and hypotension present in this patient suggest failure of the glucocorticoid system; thus, treatment with a corticosteroid is indicated. There is no evidence of sepsis; thus, antibiotics and drotrecogin alfa are not indicated. With a normal hematocrit and no reported evidence of massive hemorrhage, packed red cell transfusion is unlikely to be helpful. Although TSH production is undoubtedly low in this patient, the most immediate concern is replacement of glucocorticoid

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3183525/

questions.text: A 34y G2 who was induced for severe preeclampsia at 34 weeks has just delivered. Which is the uterotonic drug of choice in the 3rd stage of labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inj Oxytocin 10 IU IV

 

Active Management of 3rd Stage of Labor

 

  • Described by the WHO in 2007
  • Involves mainly 3 basic steps.
    • Administering a uterotonic
    • Controlled cord traction
    • Uterine massage
  • AMTSL prevents atonic PPH.
  • In 2012, the WHO issued new guidelines for AMTSL which essentially emphasized the main 3 things but with additional information which was
    • Oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice for AMTSL (10 IU IM/IV)
    • Do Controlled cord traction only if a skilled birth attendant is present.
    • Sustained uterine massage is not recommended for all women who’ve received uterotonic; instead; postpartum uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is done.
    • Delayed cord clamping (performed after 1 to 3 minutes after birth) is recommended for all births while initiating simultaneous essential newborn care (This is not to prevent atonic PPH but was introduced along with AMTSL to ensure it is followed)
  • In 2018, the WHO issued further guidelines on which other uterotonics can be used for AMTSL. These include:
    • Oxytocin (10 IU IM/IV)
    • Carbetocin (!00 mcg IM/IV)
    • Misoprostol (400 OR 600 mcg PO – to be used where Skilled birth attendant isn’t available)
    • Ergometrine/methylergometrine (200 mcg IV EXCEPT in hypertensive women))
    • Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination (5 IU/500 µg, IM)
  • Injectable prostaglandins (carboprost or sulprostone) are not recommended for the prevention of PPH
  • In this patient, methylergometrine will NOT be given as preeclampsia is a contra-indication

questions.text: A 35y asthmatic was induced for FGR at 37 weeks. She is now in the 3rd stage of labor having delivered a 2 kg female baby. Following delivery of the placenta, she starts bleeding profusely. The uterus is atonic. Which uterotone will NOT be given?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Carboprost.

 

  • Carboprost (or Prostadin) is a15-methyl analogues of PGF2α
  • It is Contraindicated in asthmatic women as it causes bronchoconstriction
  • Other drugs that are given for atonic PPH 
  1. Oxytocin
  2. Methylergometrine
  3. Oxytocin + Ergometrine (Syntometrine)
  4. Misoprostol

 

 

Ref: Page no 363, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: A female presents with significant blood loss due to postpartum hemorrhage. What would be the shock index?
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  0.9 to 1.1

 

  • Shock index = heart rate/systolic BP
  • Normal = 0.5–0.7
  • If it becomes 0.9–1.1 it indicates massive blood loss and need for intensive resuscitation.

 

Ref: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32769817/#:~:text=Abstract,detecting%20 postpartum%20 hemorrhage%20(PPH).

questions.text: A female sustained massive PPH during delivery and presented with failure of lactation and amenorrhea 1 year later. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sheehan syndrome

 

Sheehan syndrome:

 

  • Sheehan syndrome (ie, postpartum hypopituitarism) is a rare but potentially life-threatening complication.
  • The pituitary gland is enlarged in pregnancy and prone to infarction from hypovolemic shock.
  • Damage to the pituitary can be mild or severe, and can affect the secretion of one, several, or all of its hormones.
  • A common presentation is a combination of failure to lactate post delivery and amenorrhea or oligomenorrhea, but any of the manifestations of hypopituitarism (eg, hypotension, hyponatremia, hypothyroidism) can occur any time from the immediate postpartum period to years after delivery.
  • If the patient remains hypotensive after control of hemorrhage and volume replacement, she should be evaluated and treated for adrenal insufficiency immediately
  • Evaluation of other hormonal deficiencies can be deferred until four to six weeks postpartum.

 

Ref: Page no 565, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

choices.text: TXA should be administered at a dose of 1 g in 10 mL IV given as soon as PPH is identified and within 3 hours of birth. A second dose may be repeated after 15 minutes if required.
TXA should be administered at a dose of 1 g in 10 mL IV given as soon as PPH is identified and within 3 hours of birth. A second dose may be repeated after 30 minutes if required.
TXA should be administered at a dose of 0.5 g in 10 mL IV given as soon as PPH is identified and within 3 hours of birth. A second dose may be repeated after 30 minutes if required
TXA should be administered at a dose of 0.5 g in 10 mL IV given as soon as PPH is identified and within 3 hours of birth. A second dose may be repeated after 15 minutes if required

questions.text: In 2017, the WHO recommended the use of tranexamic acid (TXA) for the treatment of PPH. What is the recommended dose?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. TXA should be administered at a dose of 1 g in 10 mL IV given as soon as PPH is identified and within 3 hours of birth. A second dose may be repeated after 30 minutes if required.

 

  • The World Health Organization recommends early use of intravenous tranexamic acid (TXA) within 3 hours of birth in addition to standard care for women with clinically diagnosed postpartum hemorrhage following vaginal birth or cesarean section.
  • Administration of TXA should be considered as part of the standard PPH treatment package and be administered as soon as possible after onset of bleeding and within 3 hours of birth.
  • TXA for PPH treatment should not be initiated more than 3 hours after birth
  • TXA should be used in all cases of PPH, regardless of whether the bleeding is due to genital tract trauma or other causes.
  • TXA should be administered at a fixed dose of 1 g in 10 mL (100 mg/mL) IV at 1 mL per minute (i.e., administered over 10 minutes), with a second dose of 1 g IV if bleeding continues after 30 minutes.
  • TXA should be administered via an IV route only for treatment of PPH. Research on other routes of TXA administration is a priority.

 

REF: https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/259379/WHO-RHR-17.21-eng.pdf

questions.text: While assisting a cesarean section for placenta previa, the patient starts bleeding. The gynecologist applies the following suture on the uterus and asks the name of it. What is this suture called?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. B Lynch suture

 

  • Compression sutures are used in surgical management of PPH, usually as a 1st line option in atonic PPH
  • The following sutures have been described

 

1. B Lynch (vertical Brace): These are preferred in women who have undergone a cesarean section and the lower segment uterine incision is already there

 

 

2. Hayman suture: 2 separate sutures (brace like) without opening the cavity of the uterus

 

 

3. Cho’s sutures: multiple square sutures

 

 

4. Isthmic cervical apposition: Compression sutures in the lower uterine segment

 

 

Ref: Page no 2023, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition
